problem_type: Student selects which bar from 3 options shows an equivalent fraction to a reference bar

All bars same total length [0,1].

prompt: Which bar shows the same amount as one half?

problem_type: Student selects ALL individual bars that show equivalent fractions from a set of 3-4 bars

Bar C: divided into 6 equal intervals, 3 sections shaded (3/6). Bar D: divided into 3 equal intervals, 1 section shaded (1/3). All bars are the same total size.
action_description: Student selects Bar A (1/2), Bar B (2/4), and Bar C (3/6) as the equivalent fractions (Bar D showing 1/3 is not equivalent to 1/2), then confirms selection
prompt: Select all the bars that show equivalent fractions.

problem_type: Student selects ALL individual bars that show equivalent fractions from a set of 3-4 bars

problem_type: Student reads a scenario and determines whether a comparison is valid based on whether the wholes are the same size
workspace_description: Text-based scenario displayed: 'Mia has a granola bar. Jake has an identical granola bar. Mia ate 3/6 and Jake ate 1/2. Did they eat the same amount?' Multiple choice with 4 options.
action_description: Student selects option A: 'Yes, because the granola bars are the same size and 3/6 equals 1/2.'
prompt: Mia has a granola bar. Jake has an identical granola bar. Mia ate 3/6 and Jake ate 1/2. Did they eat the same amount?
options: Yes, because the granola bars are the same size and 3/6 equals 1/2.
No, because 3/6 and 1/2 look different.
No, because they are divided into different numbers of pieces.
Yes, because they are both granola bars.

problem_type: Student reads a scenario and determines whether a comparison is valid based on whether the wholes are the same size
workspace_description: Text-based scenario displayed: 'Two identical ribbons are cut differently. One shows 1/2 shaded, one shows 2/4 shaded. Are these amounts equivalent?' Multiple choice with 4 options.
action_description: Student selects option A: 'Yes, because the ribbons are the same size and 1/2 equals 2/4.'
prompt: Two identical ribbons are cut differently. One shows 1/2 shaded, one shows 2/4 shaded. Are these amounts equivalent?
options: Yes, because the ribbons are the same size and 1/2 equals 2/4.
No, because 1/2 and 2/4 look different.
No, because they are divided into different numbers of pieces.
Yes, because they are both ribbons.

problem_type: Student reads a scenario and determines whether a comparison is valid based on whether the wholes are the same size
workspace_description: Text-based scenario displayed: 'One pizza is small, one is large. Both have 1/2 eaten. Is the amount eaten the same?' Multiple choice with 4 options.
action_description: Student selects option A: 'No, because the pizzas are different sizes, so we cannot compare the amounts fairly.'
prompt: One pizza is small, one is large. Both have 1/2 eaten. Is the amount eaten the same?
options: No, because the pizzas are different sizes, so we cannot compare the amounts fairly.
Yes, because 1/2 equals 1/2, so the size doesn't matter.
No, because 1/2 and 1/2 are different fractions.
Yes, because they both ate part of a pizza.

problem_type: Student reads a scenario and determines whether a comparison is valid based on whether the wholes are the same size
workspace_description: Text-based scenario displayed: 'Emma ate 1/2 of her small cookie. Luis ate 2/4 of a large cookie. Can we say they ate the same amount?' Multiple choice with 4 options.
action_description: Student selects option A: 'No, because the cookies are different sizes, so we cannot compare the amounts fairly.'
prompt: Emma ate 1/2 of her small cookie. Luis ate 2/4 of a large cookie. Can we say they ate the same amount?
options: No, because the cookies are different sizes, so we cannot compare the amounts fairly.
Yes, because 1/2 equals 2/4, so the size doesn't matter.
No, because 1/2 and 2/4 are different fractions.
Yes, because they both ate part of a cookie.

problem_type: Student reads a scenario and determines whether a comparison is valid based on whether the wholes are the same size
workspace_description: Text-based scenario displayed: 'Two same-sized juice boxes. One shows 2/4 full, one shows 4/8 full. Do they have the same amount?' Multiple choice with 4 options.
action_description: Student selects option A: 'Yes, because the juice boxes are the same size and 2/4 equals 4/8.'
prompt: Two same-sized juice boxes. One shows 2/4 full, one shows 4/8 full. Do they have the same amount?
options: Yes, because the juice boxes are the same size and 2/4 equals 4/8.
No, because 2/4 and 4/8 look different.
No, because they are divided into different numbers of pieces.
Yes, because they are both juice boxes.

problem_type: Student views two equivalent fraction bars and selects the BEST explanation for why they are equivalent
workspace_description: Two fraction strips displayed. First strip: range [0,1], intervals 1/2, first interval shaded. Second strip: range [0,1], intervals 1/4, first two intervals shaded. Both strips same total size with shading and labels visible. Below the strips, 4 multiple choice explanation options.
action_description: Student selects option A: 'The same area is shaded in both bars'
prompt: Why are one half and two fourths equivalent?
options: The same area is shaded in both bars
Four is larger than two
Both fractions are less than one
They are not equivalent

problem_type: Student views two equivalent fraction bars and selects the BEST explanation for why they are equivalent

action_description: Student selects option B: 'They cover the same part of the whole'
prompt: These bars show one half and three sixths. Why are they equivalent?
options: Six is larger than two
They cover the same part of the whole
One denominator is bigger than the other
Both fractions have different numerators

problem_type: Student views two equivalent fraction bars and selects the BEST explanation for why they are equivalent

action_description: Student selects option C: 'Both bars show the same shaded amount'

Six is larger than three

problem_type: Student views two equivalent fraction bars and selects the BEST explanation for why they are equivalent
workspace_description: Two fraction strips displayed. First strip: range [0,1], intervals 1/2, first interval shaded. Second strip: range [0,1], intervals 1/8, first four intervals shaded. problem_type: Student shades parts of a bar to create a fraction equivalent to a 2/3-family reference

problem_type: Student shades parts of a bar to create a fraction equivalent to a 2/3-family reference

problem_type: Student identifies or verifies equivalence between fractions in the 2/3 family
workspace_description: Two fraction strips of equal size shown side by side for comparison. Left strip divided into thirds with 2 sections shaded. Right strip divided into sixths with 4 sections shaded.
action_description: Student selects option A: 'Yes, because both bars show the same amount shaded even though they are divided differently.'
prompt: Are two thirds and four sixths equivalent? How can you tell?
options: Yes, because both bars show the same amount shaded even though they are divided differently.
No, because thirds and sixths are different sizes.
No, because one has 2 parts shaded and the other has 4 parts.
Yes, because 2 plus 4 equals 6.

problem_type: Student identifies or verifies equivalence between fractions in the 2/3 family
workspace_description: Reference bar at top showing thirds with 1 section shaded (for comparison only). Below are three option bars of equal size: Bar A divided into sixths with 2 sections shaded, Bar B divided into sixths with 3 sections shaded, Bar C divided into sixths with 1 section shaded.
action_description: Student selects Bar A, which shows 2/6 (equivalent to the reference bar showing 1/3).
prompt: Which bar shows a fraction equivalent to one third?

problem_type: Student identifies or verifies equivalence between fractions in the 2/3 family
workspace_description: Two fraction strips of equal size shown side by side for comparison. Left strip divided into thirds with 1 section shaded. Right strip divided into sixths with 2 sections shaded.
action_description: Student selects option C: 'Yes, because the shaded amounts cover the same length on both bars.'
prompt: Compare one third and two sixths. Are they equivalent?
options: No, because six is larger than three.
No, because you can't compare fractions with different denominators.
Yes, because the shaded amounts cover the same length on both bars.
Yes, because one third is always equal to two of something.

problem_type: Student identifies or verifies equivalence between fractions in the 2/3 family
workspace_description: Reference bar at top showing sixths with 4 sections shaded (for comparison only). Below are three option bars of equal size: Bar A divided into thirds with 1 section shaded, Bar B divided into thirds with 2 sections shaded, Bar C divided into sixths with 3 sections shaded.
action_description: Student selects Bar B, which shows 2/3 (equivalent to the reference bar showing 4/6).
prompt: Find the bar that equals four sixths.

problem_type: Student identifies or verifies equivalence between fractions in the 2/3 family
workspace_description: Two fraction strips of equal size shown side by side for comparison. Left strip divided into thirds with 2 sections shaded. Right strip divided into sixths with 4 sections shaded.
action_description: Student selects option A: 'Yes, the shaded portions are equal in size.'
prompt: Do these two bars show the same amount?
options: Yes, the shaded portions are equal in size.
No, because one bar has more sections than the other.
No, because 2 and 4 are different numbers.
Yes, because both bars are the same length.

problem_type: Student determines equivalence in dialogue-framed real-world scenarios

prompt: Maya ate 1/2 of her chocolate bar. Noah ate 2/4 of an identical bar. Did they eat the same amount?
application_context: Maya and Noah each have identical chocolate bars
